doc.title: Review of the past week's data
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/JPM/JapanJapan_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/JPM

passages.text: Japan's July industrial production fell \(1.6\% \mathrm{m / m}\) sa, near our forecast of a \(1.5\%\) decline. Manufacturing output contracted \(0.2\% 3\mathrm{m / 3m}\) saar, its weakest run- rate in five months, suggesting that manufacturing activity has stabilized as the boost from front- loading ahead of US tariff hikes has faded. While auto production dampened, due possibly to the impact of US tariffs, tech production continued its upward trajectory, indicating that the global AI boom may be consistently supportive.

Manufacturers' projections suggest output growth through 3Q. Producers look for a solid \(2.8\%\) rise in August, consistent with the resilient recovery in the August PMI. With a modest \(0.3\%\) decline projected for September, these projections imply a \(6.3\%\) ar upturn through 3Q (Figure 1). It's worth noting that these numbers have been subject to large revisions over the past several months, and METI's adjusted forecast points to a \(1.7\%\) decline in August. Nonetheless, the recovery in manufacturers' sentiment, coupled with their optimistic projections, is expected to prevent a sharp contraction in manufacturing output.
Figure 1: Manufacturing output \(3\mathrm{m / 3m}\) saar, dashed line is manufacturers' projection

Tech production has been volatile this year, likely due to tariff- related fluctuations. However, after normalizing back to end- 2024 levels in 2Q, a \(2.4\% \mathrm{m / m}\) sa output rise in July may indicate solid underlying AI- related demand (Figure 2). If so, tech production is expected to maintain its upward trajectory through 2H. The inventory- to- shipments ratio fell to the lowest level since August 2022, implying that inventory rebuilding could also support output. On the flip side, auto production fell \(6.7\%\) last month, the largest decline since January 2024, possibly reflecting the impact of US auto tariffs.
Figure 2: Manufacturing output by sector 2013=100, sa

July retail sales fell \(1.6\% \mathrm{m / m}\) sa, weaker than our forecast of a \(0.2\%\) decline (Figure 3). Following a \(0.3\%\) ar quarterly contraction in 2Q, retail sales declined \(2.1\% 3\mathrm{m / 3m}\) saar, the weakest run rate since last September. The monthly drop

reflects broad- based declines across spending categories. While nominal retail sales indicate a weakening momentum at the start of this quarter, signals from this report regarding GDP real consumption can be downplayed to some extent, as the monthly decline is partly magnified by soft inbound spending and the effects of price reduction by the government policies.
Figure 3: Retail sales and consumer sentiment
Source: METI, Cabinet Office, J.P. Morgan

The Cabinet Office's August consumer confidence index sends a positive message, with the headline index rising 1.2 points to 34.9, reaching a 6- month high level in August. The recovery in consumer sentiment should also support our call for sustained growth in real consumption through 3Q. Sentiment has been adversely affected by persistent inflation, but the data suggests a sustained recovery following a sharp decline in April. While households' inflation expectations remain elevated, expectations for income growth, along with government measures to curb inflation, likely support their sentiment.

The August Tokyo CPI report indicates strong momentum in underlying inflation. While government subsidies on utility charges and the suppression of increases in other public charges are slowing the acceleration of inflation, the momentum in other prices remains robust and is broadening.

The global standard core prices (ex. food and energy) increased by \(0.1\%\) m/m sa to \(1.5\%\) oya (Figure 4). Service prices rose by \(0.2\%\) m/m sa to \(2.0\%\) oya, driven by steady demand and rising wage costs, while core goods prices showed weak movement. The decline in import prices, coupled with recent weak demand for goods, has contributed to downward pressure on core goods prices. Meanwhile, food and energy prices showed contrasting movements. Although price price inflation is gradually moderating, price increases have spread to a wide range of food products, with food inflation (ex. fresh food) rising by \(0.5\%\) m/m sa to \(7.4\%\) oya. Conversely, due to government subsidies for gasoline and electricity, energy prices fell by \(2.0\%\) m/m sa to \(- 5.3\%\) oya.
Figure 4: Tokyo core CPI
Figure 5: Tokyo services CPI
Source: Statistics Bureau, J.P. Morgan

Government price control measures have helped restrain the pace of inflation, but this is not limited to subsidies. Comparing the price increases of public services and general services within the service breakdown, public service inflation is lower than that for general services (Figure 5). In the August Tokyo CPI, public service inflation rose by \(0.3\%\) m/m sa to \(0.9\%\) oya, while general service prices rose by \(0.6\%\) m/m sa, reaching \(2.3\%\) oya. This is one reason why we expect Japan's inflation to remain sticky. The delay in adjusting public service prices raises concerns about an increased fiscal burden and the sustainability of public service operations. While price revisions are not expected in the current environment, where addressing elevated inflation is a political issue, if inflation stabilizes in the coming quarters, the government likely will start raising public service prices.

The CPI report supports our expectation of the BoJ's additional rate hike in October. We think the BoJ's claim that "underlying inflation has yet to reach the target" is becoming untenable as actual inflation continues to exceed \(2\%\) for an extended period, even as government policies have suppressed price increases.

MonMoF corporate surveySep 1%q/q saar, unless noted, nonfinancial firms8:50am3Q244Q24 1Q25 2Q25Sales1.0 3.6 6.0Current profits-35.7 57.2 -10.0Capex ex. software4.8 5.3 7.3Capex ex. software(%oya)9.5 3.1 6.9 5.5

We expect capital expenditures excluding software in the MoF corporate survey, which is a major input to the second estimate of GDP, to rise 8.0%oya in 2Q25. The first estimate of 2Q25 real GDP showed a sequential rise in capex, and high-frequency data also suggest an upward trend.

Commercial sales (Aug 29)
%m/m,saMayJunJulTotal retail sales-0.60.9-0.2-1.6%oya1.91.91.60.3

Sales of general merchandise fell 2.4%m/m sa, possibly reflecting soft inbound tourism spending. In July, there were rumors of a significant earthquake, which may have reduced tourist arrivals from Asia. Fuel sales fell 0.6%, marking the third consecutive monthly decline, likely due to falling energy prices driven by declines in oil import prices and government subsidies. Durable goods sales were notably soft, with home appliances declining 4.2%, reflecting some payback from sol-id 1H sales. On the flip side, seasonal goods sales remained relatively elevated, with apparel sales falling just 0.7% after a 2.2% rise in June.
Industrial production - preliminary (Aug 29)

Japan Economic Research Japan 29 August 2025

JunJulAugConsumer sentiment34.533.734.2 34.9Standard of living32.431.4— 32.7Income growth38.938.5— 39.4Labor market conditions38.337.6— 39.3Durables purchases28.227.4— 28.0% of respondents, "Rise" minus "fall"Inflation expectations in next 12 monthsNsa91.489.6— 91.7Sa91.389.3— 91.6
1. The DI asks whether a respondent thinks that now is a good time to purchase durables

Households' inflation expectations remain elevated, with the one- year ahead inflation expectation DI rising to 91.6. But government measures to curb rice and energy prices supported households, as evidenced by a 1.3pt rise in the standard of living index. Expectations for income growth could also help alleviate their concerns about inflation, with the income growth index rising 0.9pts to 39.4.
Sources for all data tables: ADA, JCSA, JDSA, JFA, JLM, VMA, Markit, METI, MHLW, MILT, MoF, Reuters, Statistics Bureau, J.P. Morgan forecasts.
